QuestionTxt: (For each of the following people, please tell me if you know the person and if so, whether you are very favorable, somewhat favorable, somewhat unfavorable, or very unfavorable towards the person.)... Walter Mondale

Now, I would like to ask you about other political figures. As I read each name, please tell me whether you have a FAVORABLE opinion of that person, an UNFAVORABLE opinion, or are not familiar with that person at all. Walter Mondale.

(I'm going to name some public figures and ask you what you think of them. If you haven't heard of someone I name, just tell me.) Is your opinion of...Walter Mondale...favorable, not favorable, undecided, or haven't you heard enough about...Walter Mondale...yet to have an opinion?
QuestionNote: Responses of non-voters also shown in release
StudyNote: Re-interviews with a national adult sample first interviewed in October 31-November 2, 1984.

QuestionNote: Based on responses of registered voters = 71%

(I'd like to get your feelings toward some of our political leaders and other people who are in the news these days. I will use something we call the feeling thermometer and here is how it works: I'll read the name of a person and I'd like you to rate that person using the feeling thermometer. Ratings between 50 degrees and 100 degrees mean that you feel favorable and warm toward the person. Ratings between 0 degrees and 50 degrees mean that you don't feel favorable toward the person and that you don't care too much for that person. If we come to a person whose name you don't recognize, you don't need to rate that person. Just tell me and we'll move on to the next one. If you do recognize the name, but you don't feel particularly warm or cold toward the person, you would rate the person at the 50 degree mark.)... Walter Mondale. How would you rate him using the thermometer?
SurveyOrg: Survey Research Center at University of Michigan (ANES American National Election Studies); Center for Political Studies, University of Michigan
StudyNote: A post election survey with re-interviews of 1989 (84%) of the pre-election respondents was conducted November 07, 1984-January 25, 1985.

StudyNote: The respondents were originally interviewed in the pre-election study of 2241 adults conducted September 5, 1984-November 5, 1984. Half of the post election interviews were personal, and half were by telephone. In the post election interview 2% had a short form version of the questionnaire, 98% had the long form version.
